bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 22, 1930

div1.p: Carter wishes to keep page 5, Section 1 of the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever as her father had written it without adding footnotes, but defers to Frost's judgment about maintaining historical accuracy.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 22, 1930
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 22, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
I am enclosing herewith page 5, Section i (of the MS of Father's
book as he left it at the time of his death, plus the two inserts (foot
notes x and y) which were added, after consultation with yourself, shortly
after I went over to Baltimore in the fall of 1926. Foot note x was in-
serted in accordance with Father's verbal communication to me, prior to his
death, and foot note y, as explaining Father's exact attitude in re-
gard to Noguchi's Leptospira.

At your request, I showed you this page of the original MS, when
I was last in Baltimore, at whichtime you said that you would go over
that part of the finally edited MS once more before sending it on to
New York. Indeed, I presume that you have already done so, and made such
changes as seemed advisable. Personally, I wish that we could omit both
foot notes and leave the MS as it was at the time of Father's death. I
judge, however, that this would not be quite fair, and,[unclear] although, as you
said, it has been necessary to both add and subtract a lot from the MS
l. c. in the final editing, Tthis has always been done in the interest of
historic accuracy, in which I am as much interested as Father. I do not
feel, however, that to insert foot note x, without qualifying it with the
gist of what is contained in foot note y would be in accordance with his-
toric accuracy. You, however, caring first for the truth and next for
Father (as he would have it!) can handle this matter in a manner beyond
anything that I can suggest.

I amm too sick to write a decent letter, and too blind to do
decent typing. Would be willing to take on both disabilities in an
intensified form later rather than be handicapped now, when there are
still things to be done about the book. However, I trust that I will
“pull up” within the next few days ...at least enough to “last” as long
as I can be of any use.
div1.closer: Most truly and gratefully yours, Laura A. Carter 1 enclosure.
